newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Dec 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Dec 3.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Tuesday:
- The Dow Corning Corp proposed to set aside $3 billion to pay creditors, including up to $2 billion for injury claims linked to silicone implants.
- Despite some recent data showing a cooling of the economy, the National Association of Purchasing Management's index rose to 52.7 and construction spending rose 1.8 percent in October.
- Ignoring an ultimatum from the General Motors Corp, Volkswagen AG promoted a former G.M. executive who G.M. had demanded be dismissed in the legal dispute between the two.
- Merrill Lynch named Herbert Allison Jr. as president and chief operating officer.
- Lured by a pay package of at least $50 million, Michael Fascitelli quit his partnership at Goldman Sachs to become president of Vornado Realty Trust.
- Chrysler sales rose 1.4 percent last month, thanks to increased sports utility vehicle, minivan and pickup truck sales.
- Many computer users across the nation were greeted by busy signals when they tried to take advantage of America Online's new flat rate pricing plan.

- The dollar surged to nearly two year highs of 1.5536 German marks and 1.3220 Swiss francs. - While large stocks leap up, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average past 6,500, smaller companies are watching their shares remain flat.
